content: The Act titled "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" introduces a nonrefundable personal credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation property under section 25E of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" introduces a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. The credit allows 25% of the expenditures, not exceeding $5,000 per year, for specific property improvements to mitigate hurricane and tornado damage. The Act "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" offers a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. The credit covers 25% of the expenditures, up to $5,000 per year, for designated property improvements to mitigate damage. Qualified dwelling units must be assessed at a value below $1,000,000 in specific states to be eligible for the credit. The Act allows for a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. Labor and inspection costs related to onsite preparation, assembly, or installation of the property are included in determining the qualified expenditures. The Act allows for a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures, including labor and inspection costs. Additionally, a new item is inserted after section 25D. The Act introduces a business-related credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation property, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. This credit is outlined in a new section 45O of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The hurricane and tornado mitigation credit allows for a 25% credit on qualified property expenditures, with a maximum credit of $5,000 per year. Qualified expenditures include improving roof strength, creating water barriers, enhancing roof durability, bracing walls, reinforcing roof connections, and protecting openings from debris. The qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation credit applies to expenditures on windborne debris protection for exterior doors and garages in a qualified place of business in specific states. The qualified place of business must be assessed at a value less than $5,000,000 by the local authority. The qualified states include Alabama, Arkansas, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Hawaii, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Nebraska, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, and Virginia. The taxpayer's qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures are determined based on completed onsite preparation, assembly, or installation deemed adequate by a State-certified inspector. Labor and inspection costs related to the property are also considered in the determination. Conforming amendments to the tax code include adding a new hurricane and tornado mitigation credit under section 45O(a). The amendments made by this section regarding the Hurricane and tornado mitigation credit apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007.
